Award.AbstractNarration:
BLAST 2009, 2010, 2011

The 2009-2011 BLAST conferences will be the second through fourth in a series of yearly meetings devoted to logic and related areas of mathematics based in the mountain/western midwest region. The BLAST conference series focuses on Boolean Algebra, Lattice Theory, Algebraic Logic, Universal Algebra, Set Theory, and Set-theoretic Topology.
Together, these areas form a cohesive sub-unit of logic and have strong connections with other mathematical disciplines such as Algebra, Combinatorics, General Topology, and Mathematical Physics.

The 2009 meeting will take place August 10--14, 2009, at the New Mexico State University at Las Cruces, the 2010 meeting will take place at the University of Colorado at Boulder, the 2011 meeting will take place at the University of Kansas at Lawrence.

The BLAST 2009 program includes 8 invited speakers, 4 tutorials, and 40--60 contributed talks. There will be substantial funds designated support travel and lodging for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award partially supported the second through fifth conferences in the BLAST series, which brings together researchers in Boolean Algebra, Lattice Theory, Algebraic Logic, Universal Algebra, Set Theory, and Set-theoretic Topology, along with researchers in related areas of the foundations of mathematics. The 2009 meeting was held at and partially supported by New Mexico State University. The 2010 meeting was held at and partially supported by the University of Colorado at Boulder. The 2011 meeting was held at and partially supported by the University of Kansas. The 2013 meeting was held at and partially supported by Chapman University. The NSF award was used to support the participation of invited speakers, young researchers, graduate students and under-represented groups.

Each of the supported meetings was structured around 8-9 principal lectures, 3-4 tutorial talks, and a number of contributed talks. This structure provided a balance between cutting edge research, cross-disciplinary communication and training in the foundations of mathematics.

A collection of papers from BLAST 2010 was published as a volume of the journal Order (vol. 29, no. 2, 2012).

 

BLAST 2009 (New Mexico State University)

Invited Speakers

Mick Adams (SUNY)

Alan Dow (University of North Carolina)

Marcel Erne (University of Hanover)

Miklós Maróti (Bolyai Institute, University of Szeged)

Drew Moshier (Chapman University)

Larry Moss (Indiana University)

Dilip Raghavan (Fields Institute, University of Toronto)

Yde Venema (ILLC, University of Amsterdam)

Tutorial Speakers: Topics

Rick Blute (University of Ottawa): Categorical logic

Natasha Dobrinen (University of Denver): Boolean algebra/Set theory

Peter Jipsen (Chapman University): Universal algebra

Ralph Kopperman (CUNY): Set-theoretic topology

 

BLAST 2010 (University of Colorado at Boulder)

Invited Speakers

Mohamed Bekkali (Universite Sidi Mohamed Ben Abdellah, Fez, Morocco)

Ken Kunen (University of Wisconsin)

Ralph McKenzie (Vanderbilt University)

David Milovich (Texas A&M International University)

Judith Roitman (University of Kansas)

Grigor Sargsyan (UCLA)

Juris Steprans (York University)

Friedrich Wehrung (Caen University)

Tutorial Speakers: Topics

Andreas Blass (University of Michigan): Special ultrafilters on countable sets

Gary Gruenhage (Auburn University): Topological games

Matatyahu Rubin (Ben-Gurion University): Locally moving groups and how they are used

Ross Willard (University of Waterloo): Universal algebra, Mal'cev conditions and finite relational structures

 

BLAST 2011 (University of Kansas)

Invited Speakers

Themba Dube (University of South Africa)

Todd Eisworth (Ohio University)

John Harding (New Mexico State University)

Albin Jones

Milos Kurilic (University of Novi Sad)

Keye Martin (Naval Research Laboratory)

Jorge Martinez (University of Florida)

Paul Szeptycki (York University)

Tutorial Speakers: Topics

Magdalena Grzech (Crakow University of Technology): The group of automorphisms of P(w)/fin

Pieter Hofstra (University of Ottawa): Between spaces and types

Marion Scheepers (Boise State University): Infinite games

Stevo Todorcevic (University of Toronto and CNRS, Paris): Classification programs of combinatorial set theory

 

BLAST 2013 (Chapman University)

Invited Speaker...
